DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: ANTUNES, A. P.;ANTUNES, ALEXANDRE P.;ANTUNES, ALEXANDRE;ANTUNES, ALEXANDRE PEQUENO

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduao em Engenharia Mecnica pela UFRJ(1998), mestrado em Engenharia Aeronutica e Mecnica pelo Instituto Tecnolgico de Aeronutica - ITA (2000) e doutorado em Engenharia Eletrnica e Computao pelo Instituto Tecnolgico de Aeronutica - ITA (2014). Atualmente Engenheiro de Desenvolvimento de Produtos na Embraer (2000 - ). Tem experincia no desenvolvimento de produtos aeronuticos atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: projeto de aeronaves, aerodinmica computacional, CFD e Otimizao Multidisciplinar.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: master's at Aerospace Engineering from Instituto Tecnolgico de Aeronutica (2000) and doctorate at Electric Engineering from Instituto Tecnolgico de Aeronutica (2014). Has experience in Aerospace Engineering, focusing on Aerodynamics of Space Aircraft, acting on the following subjects: cfd, launch satellite, cfd, aircraft design, wind tunnel and morphig devices.

EMBRAER - Product Development Engineer - (07/2015 - ) Laminar Flow Project - Research & Development Department Establishment of the cooperation agreement between renamed research institutions and the aerodynamic group of the project. Management of the working act
EMBRAER ? Project Manager - (07/2010 - 01/2015 ) MDO Group - Research & Development Department Management of the administrative and technical scope of the project; Integration of different engineering processes into multi-disciplinary design and optimization frameworks; Implementation of an in-house optimization algorithms(GA) and a Neural Networks.
EMBRAER - Product Development Engineering - (09/2008 - 01/2010) CFD Group - Pre-Design Department Performing aerodynamic numerical simulations of conceptual aircrafts, numerical simulations of propulsion integration and high-lift devices, gap/overlap optimization of the high-lift devices, development codes and scripts to integrate different conceptual tools, support the performance team to produce the aerodynamic database, support the environmental system team about aerodynamic calibration for icing analysis and sensor positioning.
EMBRAER - Product Development Engineering - (08/2006 - 09/2008) CFD Group - Air Management System Department Performing numerical simulations of ice accretion, aerodynamic calibration for icing wind tunnel campaigns, attending artificial icing flight campaigns, participation in internal developments with respect to icing pool of tools, numerical simulation of internal components of the air-conditioning system,
EMBRAER - Product Development Engineering - (06/2000 - 08/2006) CFD Group - Aeronautics Department Performing numerical simulations of airplane and its components: wing-fairing integration, wing-fillet aerodynamic effect, high-lift devices gap/overlap optimization, analysis of antennas and infra-red sensors installations, support the database confection, support to aerodynamic calibration for ici

LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.OBJETIVOS-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA: Desenvolvimento de ferramentas e processos de metodologias de projeto de aeronaves.
Objetivo: Realizar anlises numricas nas diversas fases do desenvolvimento de uma aeronaves e para os diferentes regimes de velocidade com intuito de aprimorar o projeto.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 34th Aerodynamic Measurement Technology and Ground Testing Conference
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DA-EDITORA: American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The present paper describes the pre-flight and post-flight work to evaluate the use of an autonomous Boundary Layer Data System (BLDS) for commercial jet aircraft surface flow measurements in the transonic flight regime. The BLDS was one of five of technologies assessed during the joint November, 2016 ecoDemonstrator program conducted in partnership by Boeing and Embraer. The BLDS is a light, compact, self-contained device that can be attached to different locations on the aircraft exterior by means of a removable structural adhesive tape. It does not require any external energy supply or modifications to the aircraft airframe; providing substantial advantages for operational flexibility. The BLDS has already been tested in the subsonic regime and encouraging results have been obtained. The present investigation in the transonic regime, up to a flight Mach number of 0.78, is a natural step forward to evaluate the capability of the BLDS system for flight test applications of interest to Boeing and Embraer. Operational requirements for commercial jet flight test, including satisfying safety-of-flight requirements, are addressed. Evaluations of boundary layer data quality and comparisons between the in-flight measured boundary layer velocity profile data and numerical simulation results are shown for wing and vertical tail survey locations. The measurements and computations agree closely at lower Mach numbers. For the highest Mach numbers there is general agreement for overall thickness, but some differences between predicted and measured profile shape details remain for the wing boundary layer. Overall, the BLDS was found to provide a flexible, low-cost approach to boundary layer data acquisition that is compatible with the requirements of commercial jet flight test.
